posts.com:
/lit/ is for the discussion of literature, specifically books (fiction & non-fiction), short stories, poetry, creative writing, etc. If you want to discuss history, religion, or the humanities, go to /his/. If you want to discuss politics, go to /pol/. Philosophical discussion can go on either /lit/ or /his/, but those discussions of philosophy that take place on /lit/ should be based around specific philosophical works to which posters can refer.

Check the wiki, the catalog, and the archive before asking for advice or recommendations, and please refrain from starting new threads for questions that can be answered by a search engine.

/lit/ is a slow board! Please take the time to read what others have written, and try to make thoughtful, well-written posts of your own. Bump replies are not necessary.

Looking for books online? Check here:
Guide to #bookz

http://b-ok.cc/

Recommended Literature

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21577365
Form is a paradigmatic (i.e. formal & teleological) power, not an object or thing, that shapes plastic matter (receptacles) through instrumental causes: a potency to shape matter to a purposeful end. Artifical form is transcendent to the thing and creates artifacts, organic form is immanant to the thing and creates organisms.

Whether the universe as a whole is artificial, because its formal and teleological cause is outside of the universe, or organic, because its form and end comes from within itself and for itself, is an open question. I prefer the latter, otherwise life is just an artificial and arbitrary game by God to score heaven/hell points in, and is inherently meaningless in-itself.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21564359
try "Athenaze", you can even ehm borrow it from the link in the OP if you want to give it a try, these kind of books were made for people to take it slow and comfy if you don't have time constraints
I used it and I'm reading both Thucydides and Homer right now
knowing Latin though does help a lot, but it's not necessary, it will just make the process easier

to simplify it a lot you will learn initially the Greek spoken by Plato in the Athens of the fifth-fourth century, which is the basis of Koine, which largely is a simplified version of it, and it's also a sister dialect to Ionic, which is the base of Homer
once your Attic will be good enough, moving to other dialects won't be too hard, especially Ionic; Homer it's kind of it's own thing, as it's an artificial poetic language whose main challenge is really the lexicon not so much the odd forms which you get used to fairly easily

GRRM: Fantasy is all very well, but it mustn't be escapism. We need tax plans. We need mud. We need dysentery.

JRRT: We do?

GRRM: If our hero spends time in prison, he should get dysentery.

JRRT: I don't know that we want to wallow in the sordid.

GRRM: After two weeks he should be shitting brown water.

JRRT: <At the end of his tether> Well . . .

GRRM: People need to face reality.

JRRT: I fought in the trenches through the First World War. You?

GRRM: . . .

JKR: <Seeing her chance to turn this project into a two-person affair>: I have to side with Professor Tolkien here. Grunge is so 1990. Let's keep the tone reasonably aspirational.

JRRT: Aspirational. What a splendid sentiment, young lady. Now we just need a plot. Never was much good at those, myself.

JKR: <Diffident> I have an idea we could use. There's just one difficulty.

JRRT: Oh?

JKR: <Cunning> The scenario I have in mind would require the invention of a whole new language.

JRRT: <Eyes lighting up> That doesn't sound like an insurmountable obstacle.

JKR: I don't know. I'm not really sure I'm up to it.

JRRT: One doesn't want to blow one's own trumpet, but I fancy I could take a crack at that part.

JKR: You could? Well . . . We might even need TWO languages.

JRRT: <Puffs on his pipe in excitement> TWO languages, you say?

GRRM: If I could just make a suggestion —

JKR: No. You couldn't. <To Tolkien> So, if you could handle the language part, I think I could manage the plot. Would you be OK with a feisty female character?

JRRT: A female character? Hmmm. Never considered that.

<He lights his pipe absent-mindedly>

It's a crazy idea, but do you know, I think it might work. It might work.

JKR: Great.

JRRT: She'd have to go in an Appendix, of course.

JKR: An Appendix.

JRRT: You were thinking of putting her in the main body of the work? Don't want to lose the reader's attention. Keen young chaps, want to hear about battles and goblins and so on. Put a woman in, and you might lose them.

JKR: <Weighing her feminist principles against the chance to get into the Western Canon> Yes, you're right. Just in an Appendix, then.

JRRT: Splendid. By the way, where's that other fellow? He seems to have wandered off.

JKR: Never mind about him. Let's get some lunch. You know, John Ronald — may I call you John Ronald? — I have a good feeling about this.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Had a relatively unique college experience.

Was a terrible high school student. So I went to community college. Loved it. Met professors with a passion for teaching and really got into my interest when I was allowed to pursue it freely. Joined a ton of clubs and made a ton of friends with really genuine people. But it was definitely hard to be taken seriously. Turns out most colleges love transfers, because the likelihood of them dropping out is very low.

Transferred to an ivy league in NY. The students were all pretty neurotic. Teachers didn't care about teaching you the material. They teach you about their specific research to try and recruit for their labs. Then they test you with ridiculous questions to trip up the smart nerds to try and get a median grade around 60%. Then they curve you up to an A or B so you're actually hirable. Terrible learning experience. But incredible opportunities for research, work, internships, etc. Can't get into volunteering clubs because they have a hyper competitive application process because all of the pre-med students also want to put it on their resume. You can't make club friends unless you join a hobby club so silly that no one would dare put it on their resume.

Overall community college was a far superior learning experience. But the ivy league helped me get some upward mobility. Got most of my substantive growth and work ethic from my community college, but the name of the ivy league on my resume got me the career success.

Cough syrup causes me to kind of lose my mind and become super paranoid and/or detached. Specifically become incredibly paranoid that others are watching me all the time.
Super isolated and start fasting obsessively and cutting myself out of a desire to punish myself. Repeatedly think about killing myself, and at points try the door handles to different roofs and tying my belt over my head just thinking about kicking the chair beneath me. ....
Everyone in the dorm dislikes me , or views me with mocking indifference, the way you'd look at a gross, but harmless insect. Only kid who at all seems interested in me is this other kind of odd ball, who makes a repeated effort to get to know me, but I keep my distance. First introduce myself to everyone about a week in coming back incredibly drunk from a coworkers party (I worked at a pub). Sit down in the kind of living space, and start rambling drunkenly in hysterics about how I don't know anyone and am so lonely. Dont make friends in my classes either because they're massive lecture halls.
Kind of friends with the students at my job, but not really. More like they'd out of courtesy invite me to parties. Drink insane amounts & end up in hospital twice, had to take some class. Lose touch with them after 1st yr.
>2nd year
Room with two mentally ill strangers I found off facebook. One is an autistic savant music grad, the other was an OCD cripplingly shy poli sci major and first generation student.
The latter I got along with okay, we'd sometimes drink together, but we were both kind of awkward and maybe too similar to each other. I did like him all the same. He was a Catholic Marxist fag (you can't make this shit up....), and really very kind of demure, painfully self-conscious.
"are we weird?" I remember him asking me one night.
I have zero memory of my classes. I took classes but for the life of me can't remember anything about them. All I remember was
>3rd year
COVID hits at end of 2nd year and I move back in with my parents. Lose all contact with former roommates, never contact them again. Entire 3rd year is online, and I basically remember nothing about it.
At that point I had decided to major in English, but already kind of regretted the decision, but felt there was no turning back.
The English teachers I remember being weirdly more political than even my Poli Sci teachers. 1/2

>Immanuel Kant (1724-1804) is generally considered the greatest of modern philosophers. I cannot myself agree with this estimate

>Kant gives as an illustration of the working of the categorical imperative that it is wrong to borrow money, because if we all tried to do so there would be no money left to borrow. One can in like manner show that theft and murder are condemned by the categorical imperative. But there are some acts which Kant would certainly think wrong but which cannot be shown to be wrong by his principles, for instance suicide; it would be quite possible for a melancholic to wish that everybody should commit suicide. His maxim seems, in fact, to give a necessary but not a sufficient criterion of virtue. To get a sufficient criterion, we should have to abandon Kant’s purely formal point of view, and take some account of the effects of actions. Kant, however, states emphatically that virtue does not depend upon the intended result of an action, but only on the principle of which it is itself a result; and if this is conceded, nothing more concrete than his maxim is possible.

>Kant maintains, although his principle does not seem to entail this consequence, that we ought so to act as to treat every man as an end in himself. This may be regarded as an abstract form of the doctrine of the rights of man, and it is open to the same objections. If taken seriously, it would make it impossible to reach a decision whenever two people’s interests conflict.

>The “thing-in-itself” was an awkward element in Kant’s philosophy, and was abandoned by his immediate successors, who accordingly fell into something very like solipsism. Kant’s inconsistencies were such as to make it inevitable that philosophers who were influenced by him should develop rapidly either in the empirical or in the absolutist direction; it was, in fact, in the latter direction that German philosophy moved until after the death of Hegel.

The Fool’s Interruption

It is no misanthrope who has written this book; nowadays the hatred of man is too expensive. To hate man as one did previously, Timonically, completely, without qualification, with one’s whole heart, from an utter love of hatred – to that end one would have to renounce contempt – and how much subtle enjoyment, how much patience, how much amiableness, even, do we owe to our contempt! Moreover, in this we are the ‘elect of God’: subtle contempt is our taste and our prerogative, our art, our virtue perhaps, we, the most modern of the moderns!

Hatred, on the other hand, equalizes, places on the same level – in the end, hatred shows respect; there is fear in hatred, a great deal of fear. However, we fearless ones, we who are the most intellectual men of the age, know our advantage well enough to live without fear as the most intellectual of this age. We are hardly likely to be beheaded, locked up or banished; we are not even likely to have our books banned or burned.

The age loves intellect, it loves us and needs us, even when it is given to understand that we are artists of contempt; that all dealings with people make us shudder; that all our mildness, patience, humanitarianism and civility cannot persuade our nose to dismiss its prejudice against the proximity of man; that we love nature all the more when it is least humane, and art precisely when it is the artist’s flight from man, or his mockery of man, or his mockery of himself …

Yes, about half the entries of my diary T.B.H. (not to be confused with imitators) make me weep at the sheer wonder of my life, character and endeavours, the endless grace with which I move and act in this vale of tears, outshined solely by the overwhelming and frankly awe-inspiring beauty which which I document my liaisons, my thrysts, my conquests, all facets and minutiae of the literary lifestyle - in which it would actually be wrong to say I participate, for this lifestyle itself is, indeed, rather modelled on my personal exploits.
Just recently, I was reminiscing (for winter is indeed the time of reminiscence) of my time in London in 2019, during my second Grand Tour of Europe, where I went to the Royal Albert Hall to see their rendition of Mozart's Zauberflöte, only to leave immediately after the Papageno-Papagena duet, to rendezvouz with an Estonian prostitute, whose anus and rectum was vigorously and passionately massaged by my erect tongue, my bass moans, enshrouded by her pale cheeks, conducting, in unison with her moans, a duet that was an even greater expression of love than Mozart could ever reach with an orchestra.
I wept a solitary and silent tear for my life, the unadulterated beauty and unfettered joy of the literary lifestyle, and then another, for all those who dare not seize it, but insist that the grapes with which I intoxicate myself in ecstacy are sour.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21578350
Honestly trail and error is the best way. Most of the basics can be picked up from any bookbinding tutorial.

If i had to give one piece of advice, its not to worry about machinery and tools. Lots of "traditional" bookbinders have all sorts of obscure and expensive tools for sewing and pressing their books, and these tools have benefits, but a needle, a thread, a handsaw, and the force of gravity are all thats really needed to bind a book. Both books in pic related were bound without using any "bookbinding tools", so dont get discouraged or think you need a workshop to do this, probably you apready have everything you need.

The one thing that is hard to find is the board that hardcovers are made from. The technical term for this kind of board is "chipboard". Its basically sawdust particles, and comes in all sorts of weight. The easiest way to get this is to walk into a hardware store and ask to see their chipboard, which is usually with the lumber and drywall. Its much easier to get the chipboard cut in store than t cut it yourself, so figure out your basoc dimensions beforehand (A1, A2, etc.) and ask them to cut it for you.

For glue, you want to use Polyvinyl Acetate, commonly known as Wood Glue. Its durable, easy to use, and bonds well to paper/chipboard. It also has a neutral PH, so it wont discolour your paper. If possible, try to use acid free paper as well, for the same reasons.

>>21575798
>So you're basically saying will to power is the capacity to shape the world around you in your own image?
A different anon here, but I would argue it's not about capacity at all. Will to power is the drive every living thing has to, in essence, challenge, overcome, and strengthen itself. It is a metaphysical claim, much like Schopenhauer's will to life. Gaining external power and control over others may be something someone does as part of it, but so would be gaining internal power (or mastery of ones self in other words). It is not a set of values Nietzsche is extolling, it is him trying to understand a mechanic of reality. When you look at how he considers power, this passage might make it clearer
>I have found strength where one does not look for it: in simple, mild, and pleasant people, without the least desire to rule—and, conversely, the desire to rule has often appeared to me a sign of inward weakness: they fear their own slave soul and shroud it in a royal cloak (in the end, they still become the slaves of their followers, their fame, etc.) The powerful natures dominate, it is a necessity, they need not lift one finger. Even if, during their lifetime, they bury themselves in a garden house!
WTP has as much of a goal as evolution does, it is a continuous process of living beings constantly conflicting with themselves and others.
>To have a creative vision of greatness and to impose it on the world?
Someone taking a Nietzschean approach might ask
>"What is greatness to you?"
The Christians have a great vision that they want to impose (or bring forth), so do the Communists, the Nazis, and a multitude of other peoples. Sound out your values and see what is underneath them. Are they healthy? What assumptions do rest on? Do they affirm life instead of deny it? Again, these value do not have to be anything about controlling others as the other anons seem to say. Nietzsche admired Caesar and Napoleon, but also Homer, Leonardo, and Goethe as great men and creators for 'the right to throw off a faith'. It is overcoming of old and creation of new, 'better' values that is the most important conscious decision. The reason it may hard to to determine how to 'expand your power' could be because it will always remain nebulous without a firm hold on what you value (this is complete conjecture, feel free to call it bullshit)

>>21572712
I *think* Will to Power was something of a misunderstanding by Nietzsche, before impulses and instincts were understood. If an infant is determined to learn to walk, and to speak, this could be regarded as a 'will to power'. Because the earth was widely believed to be only a few thousand years old, immense stretches of evolutionary time were consciously or unconsciously ignored. It seems obvious enough now that instinctive muscle and brain activity are inbuilt in babies, so almost all will move, walk, and talk. It's similar to birds leaving their nests: they have wings, and not much to do with them but flap them. Bertrand Russell thought the impulse to learn science was a search for power. And the impulse to learn languages and act might have a similar root. I think feedback from the external world is necessary. But I *think* the 'Will to Power' is an overstatement, an over-impressive phrase which has misled many people. Let me amplify the point. Probably there are natural sequences in events; eyesight needs to be learnt, body movements controlled, limits understood, pain found and avoided. I'm told kittens who had their eyelids sewn together, and later unsewn, never learn full seeing. By the age of two, the 'terrible twos' set in, perhaps caused by frustration at personal limits. It seems that if reading is not learned (perhaps after years of the 'look say' method) it may never be fluent. Abnormal silences and forbiddings can delay speech permanently. But children, and adults feeling the time is right for anything from running to polite speech, from cooking to oratory, aren't showing 'will to power' trying these things; all they're doing is getting to a normal level for their group or race. Probably, anyway.
The Individualism myth was a very successful misdirection, particularly in the USA, where there was new territory, controlled discreetly and mostly remotely and anonymously. Co-operation between large groups of people was discouraged by propaganda, money, and violence. Instead, people were told to look for a Great Man. Almost like they want us to believe in one-man superheroes, as a distraction from the reality that large groups, operating secretly, and specializing in disparate aspects of power (propaganda, teaching, food, work, law, transport...), in practice can be far more important. I think Nietzsche's reputation, whenever it's fanned into life, is absurdly inflated.

Letter from a novel im writing sort of camp of the saints zombie apocalypse esque thing with multiple characters. i thought it was touching but perhaps to personal what do you think?
A Love Letter To A Southern Daughter
Dear Josephine,

Don’t Those days of ours seem so far away from us now? I have the impulse to write to your old address. You can’t still be there, I know, but do you remember Josephine? When we heard antebellum and thought “What a beautiful word” of white columns and cornbread. Even then it was already a distant memory to our parents and now it's well and truly dead. That dreamy phrase which for us held the keys to a gilded age when they called our Great-Grandparents Planters and our Grandfathers' knights. Ohh but Sweet One do you recall? We’d sit inside the magnolia at sunset and through its luster leaves light would peek and we’d dream of our own personal New York City night. Now the night is all I have.
Oh dear those were the gilded days when the Sun laid its heavy yoke on our sunburnt backs, My love how I wish to have stayed there, tracing Cherokee paths with my Moccasined princess. Through the Humid Piedmont hills we strolled and splashed in creeks to cool ourselves. Our Rome My Love! Our Rome!
I think I know what your grandmama meant when she said antebellum. My voice cracks when I think of Georgia. The way hers would when she would sing to us. About her farm, and about Sherman and the fires and the bees. “He even burnt the bees” She’d crack with a tear in her eye. We didn't understand, how could we sweet Josephine? Now I do because I cry thinking of her bees the farm which I never saw and her old slave maid. They remind me of you and what the tide has taken from us, our inheritance.

With Love, a Southern Son.

I used to buy into anti-natalism but have since changed my view given the incoherence of non-existence. Only existence "is", non-existence "is not" and necessarily cannot obtain. So what? Suppose that existence is identical to consciousness, for what exists necessarily exists for a subject (subject and object are inseparable). If that is the case, then opting out of procreation makes no difference, because Being/existence is indivisible (per Parmenides' arguments). All contingent beings are determinations of existence, but in being grounded upon Being/existence, which makes particular existents possible (being that which underlies them, and thus presupposed in all determinations therein), no addition or negation of an existent can have any genuine impact upon existence as a whole; nothing can come from nothing. Returning to my identification of existence/Being with consciousness given the inseparability of subject and object, existence is eternal, for Being comes from Being, so no action of contingent mortals can have any bearing on that.

https://www.abolitionist.com/anti-natalism.html

>Benatar's policy prescription is untenable. Radical anti-natalism as a recipe for human extinction will fail because any predisposition to share that bias will be weeded out of the population. Radical anti-natalist ethics is self-defeating: there will always be selection pressure against its practitioners. Complications aside, any predisposition not to have children or to adopt is genetically maladaptive. On a personal level, the decision not to bring more suffering into the world and forgo having children is morally admirable. But voluntary childlessness or adoption is not a global solution to the problem of suffering.

>Yet how should rational moral agents behave if - hypothetically - some variant of Benatar's diagnosis as distinct from policy prescription was correct?

>In an era of biotechnology and unnatural selection, an alternative to anti-natalism is the world-wide adoption of genetically preprogrammed well-being. For there needn't be selection pressure against gradients of lifelong adaptive bliss - i.e. a radical recalibration of the hedonic treadmill. The only way to eradicate the biological substrates of unpleasantness - and thereby prevent the harm of Darwinian existence - is not vainly to champion life's eradication, but instead to ensure that sentient life is inherently blissful. More specifically, the impending reproductive revolution of designer babies is likely to witness intense selection pressure against the harmfulness-promoting adaptations that increased the inclusive fitness of our genes in the ancestral environment of adaptation. If we use biotechnology wisely, then gradients of genetically preprogrammed well-being can make all sentient life subjectively rewarding - indeed wonderful beyond the human imagination. So in common with "positive" utilitarians, the "negative" utilitarian would do better to argue for genetically preprogrammed superhappiness.

>Gibbon's style is detestable, but his style is not the worst thing about him. His history has proved an effectual bar to all real familiarity with the temper and habits of imperial Rome. Few persons read the original authorities, even those which are classical; and certainly no distinct knowledge of the actual state of the empire can be obtained from Gibbon's rhetorical sketches. He takes notice of nothing but what may produce an effect; he skips on from eminence to eminence, without ever taking you through the valleys between: in fact, his work is little else but a disguised collection of all the splendid anecdotes which he could find in any book concerning any persons or nations from the Antonines to the capture of Constantinople. When I read a chapter in Gibbon, I seem to be looking through a luminous haze or fog:—figures come and go, I know not how or why, all larger than life, or distorted or discoloured; nothing is real, vivid, true; all is scenical, and, as it were, exhibited by candlelight. And then to call it a History of the Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire!

>Was there ever a greater misnomer? I protest I do not remember a single philosophical attempt made throughout the work to fathom the ultimate causes of the decline or fall of that empire. How miserably deficient is the narrative of the important reign of Justinian! And that poor scepticism, which Gibbon mistook for Socratic philosophy, has led him to misstate and mistake the character and influence of Christianity in a way which even an avowed infidel or atheist would not and could not have done. Gibbon was a man of immense reading; but he had no philosophy; and he never fully understood the principle upon which the best of the old historians wrote. He attempted to imitate their artificial construction of the whole work—their dramatic ordonnance of the parts—without seeing that their histories were intended more as documents illustrative of the truths of political philosophy than as mere chronicles of events.

>The true key to the declension of the Roman empire—which is not to be found in all Gibbon's immense work—may be stated in two words:—the imperial character overlaying, and finally destroying, the national character. Rome under Trajan was an empire without a nation.
t. coleridge

Norman Mailer gave six tips for writing. Here's the last one:

6. Don’t Open The Pressure Cooker (Of Your Current Writing Ideas).
‘I think it’s bad to talk about one’s present work, for it spoils something at the root of the creative act. It discharges the tension.’


You could draw your friend's attention to this if he's a little too generous with his sharing. I found it here:

https://www.writerswrite.co.za/6-writing-tips-from-norman-mailer/

The article goes on to say:

"A lot of writers, including Stephen King, share this opinion. Do you?

When writers discuss a work-in-progress to their friends and family, it’s like opening up a pressure cooker. All the good stuff escapes right out the top and might dissipate.

Once you start talking about the plot twists, you might keep talking and make drastic plot changes based on what readers have said.

Sometimes discussing your article or story before it’s done can mean that someone else’s opinion is having an unwelcome influence on your work before it’s completed.

Want to show off your plot?

Get draft one on paper first."

You could always have it so much worse. But you are here. You have unlimited access to almost all of mankind's accumulated knowledge, right at your fingertips and either on your desk or in your pocket. You are not, for example, living a life of nonstop danger, hunger, disease, misery and exploitation like the poor fuckers working in Congolese cobalt mines or the children making clothes in a sweatshop in Malesia, all for the benefit of richer, better-off people across the great oceans, and all for a mere pittance.

You have opportunities. You have sufficient food and water and shelter. You have excesses, many of which you have already grown tired of -- toys that you have played with aplenty, maybe even ones you haven't played with at all. From their perspective, and even from the perspective of kings long gone and only still seen on the pages of history books and paintings, you are living a life of luxury.

The Eden story isn't about a physical event but it builds on real history.

Astrology comes from the Atlanteans, little details like Atlas being the first astronomer keep reinforcing this idea. The biggest disaster happened due to a comet breaking apart in the atmosphere 12.000 years ago. It may have caused repeated disasters with a warning in the sky well in advance each time. In that context a focus on studying the stars makes sense.

>>21555032
A very good and tricky question. We know through Aristotle and quotations of Speussipus and Xenocrates that the latter two heads of the Academy departed self-consciously departed from Plato's view, apparently, of the Form Numbers, and the latter two in quotation also argue that Aristotle misunderstands or misrepresents Plato's views; that the Academy between then and Cicero's time became more skeptical leaning makes it hard to establish just what the dogmas or traditions of the school were. Numenius, who Plotinus read (but didn't necessarily take as the final word) seems to combine views of both the early and skeptical school by claiming Euthyphro was written to criticize popular Athenian religious practice uing the ridiculous Euthyphro as a proxy.

Porphry's bography seems to admit that there's innovation in Plotinus, but it's not clear what he thinks the full extent of that is:

>"Plotinus’ writing is concise, but packed with meaning; brief and more abundant in ideas than in words, inspiring and passionate about almost everything; a *combination of personal insight and respect for tradition*. Stoic and Peripatetic doctrines are blended into his writings, though they are not obvious; and it contains the concentrated essence of
Aristotle’s Metaphysics."

Aristotle's commentator Alexander of Aphrodisias takes Aristotle and Plato to be opposed, but Plotinus seems to take them as either harmonized or harmonizable; the treatise on Potentiality and Actuality are clearly focused on Aristotelian nomenclature, though perhaps with adjustments or corrects to fit them to what Plotinus takes to be Plato's views or an innovation acceptable to such (for Plato on Potentiality, cf. Theaetetus and Sophist).

There's also some kind of acknowledgement of having to grapple with texts, presumably including the Platonic corpus, but also a suggestion of how to read:

>"For three days I, Porphyry, questioned his account of the sense in which the soul
was ‘in’ the body, and he patiently went through the arguments. Someone
called Thaumasius, who was studying universal propositions, joined the
seminar and wanted to hear Plotinus speaking on texts: he could not stand
Porphyry’s responding and questioning. However, Plotinus said: ‘But if
we cannot solve Porphyry’s difficulties when he asks them, how will we be
able to say anything at all when faced with a text?’"

There's some sense that he's not merely reiterating the teachings passed down to him:

>"I decided to set out this letter to substantiate the claim that there were those who, during his lifetime, thought that Plotinus made his reputation by passing off Numenius’ doctrines as his own." (But compare "On another occasion, Origen appeared at a seminar. Plotinus blushed deeply and wanted to leave. Origen asked him to keep speaking, but he said that all desire to do so is crushed when the speaker sees that he is speaking to those who know what he is going to say.")

(Cont.)

>>21565106
The glossary of my edition (Gerson) renders it as substance. I'll write out the entry here:
>Substance (ούσιά ): also substance, Substantiality, substantiality. Term with both Platonic and Peripatetic provenance. When used Platonically, Substance refers to Intellect or to any distinct Being in the intelligible world; Substantiality refers to the essence of Intellect or of any distinct Being. Intelligibles, that is, Platonic Forms, are variously referred to as Substances or the Subtantialiy of Intellect. When used Peripatetically , the term 'substance' refers to an individual 'this something'; 'substantiality' refers to the essence of a substance, that is, its core reality or being. For Plotinus, true ontological primacy is found in Substance and Substantiality, not in substance and substantiality. Nevertheless, Plotinus follows Aristotle in making a distinction between Substance and Substantiality in the intelligible world which reflects Aristotle's distinction between substance and substantiality in the sensible world. The adjective substantial, Substantial usually indicate and implicit contrast. Thus, Substantial Numbers are contrasted with quantitative (i.e., non-substantial) number.

>In later Hellenistic philosophy, particularly in Neoplatonism, the concept of ousia took on a more mystical and metaphysical meaning, where it was understood as the ultimate reality or ultimate being, which is transcendent, eternal, and unchanging. Why is that even important? Plato himself didn't write down any systematic explanation of his own philosophy. He wrote dialogues that present a dialectic and let the reader reach their own conclusions on the matter based on the arguments. They're made to be extrapolated. Plotinus exegetes Plato in the same way Christians exegete the Bible and the result is a beautiful flowering of the themes Plato touched on.

If you're going to be an autist then it's not likely Plato thought everything that Plotinus ascribes to his philosophy but that's only because Plotinus takes Plato and builds his works into a full fledged holistic philosophical worldview. Plotinus transcends Plato and in that regard whether or not he's adhering to Platos own personal philosophy is irrelevant.

2.8 Why Distant Objects Appear Small

As objects get further away, light concentrates down proportionate to our pupils
- things further away are more form than matter, since they appear stripped of qualities
- some other possible explanations

Is magnitude similar in size and sound?
- as objects and sounds are observed further away, size and sound both weaken

Maybe because there is more variety of forms at a further distance, the eye makes the greater volume of things appear simple to process everything

Close up, more volume of an object can be observed since there is less form and space involved

2 the explanation by lesser angle of vision as reducing appearance
- can't explain things that are bigger than we can see, like the sky
..
The long paragraph before 2. almost sounded sollipsistic, but honestly I thought it was a very interesting kind of phenomenal account. We don't perceive things in 6 dimensions or 7, we process phenomena the way its relayed through SPs and their extention through science instruments. It kind of seems productive in some sense to say stuff like "the eye makes the volume more simplistic close up because there are less forms". I can't put my finger on it exactly but it sounds like the precursor of some spatial theory that isn't atomistic at its core. Or it could also be nonsense.

>>21578338
In the original-language text, the two occurrences of “God” (Greek, the·osʹ) at John 1:1 are grammatically different. In the first occurrence, the word “God” is preceded by the Greek definite article, while the article does not appear before the second occurrence.

Many scholars note that the absence of the definite article before the second the·osʹ is significant.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21578448
That's what I'm saying

the Greek word θεός (the·osʹ) is a singular predicate noun occurring before the verb and is not preceded by the definite article. This is an anarthrous the·osʹ. The God with whom the Word, or Logos, was originally is designated here by the Greek expression ὁ θεός, that is, the·osʹ preceded by the definite article ho. This is an articular the·osʹ.

The articular construction of the noun points to an identity, a personality, whereas a singular anarthrous predicate noun preceding the verb points to a quality about someone.

Therefore, John’s statement that the Word, or Logos, was “a god” or “divine” or “godlike” does not mean that he was the God with whom he was. It merely expresses a certain quality about the Word, or Logos, but it does not identify him as one and the same as God himself.

>For a minute, perhaps longer, standing on the pavement, he stared in disbelief at the blacked-out window, till anger, shame and finally self-disgust broke in him together like a physical anguish and he turned and hurried blindly back towards the King’s Road. Who was it this time? Another beardless ballet dancer, performing some narcissistic ritual? Her vile cousin Miles, the career politician? Or a one-night Adonis spirited from the nearby pub?

Too, from the reader's perspective, Karla's taunting of him on this subject with the lighter, as well as Bill Haydon with the cucking, weave the Ann subplot into the fabric of the narrative in a very interesting way.

>>21571536
Why are you surprised? Have you tried opening a pdf in Koreader?
PDF is just a container and the actual content can be wildly different. What I assume most people associate pdfs with are textbooks and other pdf-published literature.
What I sometimes read are scanned books (pdf/djvu) that weren't yet processed into typical ebook formats. And Koreader handles them with ease, trimming white margins to fit the content to width.
Quality of text depends on the skill of file creator, but on e-ink it looks better than on a laptop screen (subjective).
Paperwhite's 6.8" screen is sufficient for the books I choose to read this way. Sophocles tragedies were the last one. Actually perfect for scanned poems.

For "normal" pdfs that were created from text (and even files with OCR) there's reflow function.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Nous is thinking/intellection designated in a general way

Thinking/intellection is evidently a part of reality, it's something we can "see" in nature - in ourselves most intimately, and by analogy in other things which we take to be thinking because they behave in ways similar to us

As a part of nature it needs to be explained

In particular it has to be explained as distinct from non-thinking matter, which has a lot of features like: changeability, coming into being (in composite bodies) and breaking apart again, movement, desire for things not already possessed, etc. Non-thinking being in general seems to have a lot of impermanence and shifting around inherent to it.

Intellection on the other hand, as we use it, functions precisely by finding what is stable and non-shifting, what is essential and not accidental, in non-thinking being. We can think the essences and natures of things even when those things are not present or have been destroyed, etc. We can think the form of something that is not yet actual or present. Intellection seems to participate in atemporality, in permanence, as a necessary complement to the temporality and impermanence of the sensuous material it encounters and finds forms "in."

There seems to be an analogy between sense (mental experience of sensuous material) and sensuous material (matter itself). Both are impermanent and shifting. But intellection can remain "the same" as it governs over a sensation; it also seems to remain "the same" within a sensuous body insofar as it causes that body to maintain its essential structure despite accidental changes and fluctuations in its material manifestation.

Given this analogy or parallel between the "form that is thought by the mind, as being IN the material thing and making or holding it as what it is," and the "form that is thought by the mind, as being JUST in the mind, as separated from any embodiment," it is worth inquiring whether "Mind," Nous, Intellection, which can "hold" forms "over" their material instantiations (both in reality and in imagination), is all ONE entity, in which BOTH the formed-ness of things participate, AND we participate insofar as we think/see the forms in things

Now read bk1 of Aristotle's Metaphysics where he talks about why Anaxagoras' Nous was getting close to Plato's concept of the Ideas

In modern Greek 'nous' (pronounced 'noos') means mind. We usually use it to say 'have you lost your mind?' or we have a saying which means 'bring back your mind' ie come back to reality.

I'd say in Socratic times this word was more versatile, for me (having a decent grip of Ancient Greek from school) it always meant a sort of high awareness or high power of reason. In some dialogues it just means good sense though. Depends on emotional context, like much of Greek.

posts.com:
>>21575799
It's an (initially) unaccountable feature of nous/noesis itself:
>διὰ τὸ θαυμάζειν οἱ ἄνθρωποι καὶ νῦν καὶ τὸ πρῶτον ἤρξαντο φιλοσοφεῖν.
>[It was] because of wonder [that] men began to philosophize, both now and at the beginning.
Also sometimes translated as "philosophy begins in wonder."

This also leads to the very platonic paradox: if the desire to render accounts (logoi) of things, to understand and explain (to philosophize), is initially unaccountable, is just something we do and manifestly find ourselves doing, then it is ITSELF an explanandum (a thing needing explanation, a thing to be explained). Hence the focus of all Platonism on this "eros," or non-cognitive or pre-cognitive "desire," that pushes/pulls us toward adequate understanding of the world even before we know that we are understanding anything. This survives all the way down to Kant's regulative ideal of the world's harmony and explainability, i.e., we naturally see and WANT to understand the world as a uniform and well-ordered whole, even when we are unaware of this assumption.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21575818
You should read 1.1. of the Enneads, the soul can be used equivocally to mean both the particular individual soul embodied in some being and the higher intellectual principle that grounds it. Plotinus resorts to very platonic metaphors of light (illumination and reflection) to explain how the higher principles like Intellect are "contained in" our particular instantiated forms (the individual Socrates, you, perhaps individual animals depending on your view) WITHOUT making those higher principles coterminous with them as they are instantiated in us. The forms are present in us, in a way, but they are also not present in us in a way - we participate in them, we channel them or they illuminate our thoughts by shining through us from behind.

Later scholastic philosophy uses the language of "contraction": a higher form or hypostasis "contracts" itself to a lesser or more limited potential form or aspect of itself in order to instantiate.

Do you think they watch all that is going on and sit mute, disinterested, with no care for any of these things -- or are they willing to petition the Father on behalf of those "still running the race"? The saints are in heaven, alive in Christ. It is what, in the Nicene Creed, is called the Communion of Saints. They can hear our prayers and intercede for us, as clearly taught in Hebrews and the Book of Revelation.

>>21574702
>but not their guilt like Catholics teach.
That can be found in Augustine (i.e., the idea that all men are personally guilty for Adam's sin), but the Catholic Church never adopted the entirety of his teaching in this regard, and it is not actually Catholic teaching.

The point is addressed here from an EO perspective:

>The attempt to make the term “Original Sin” synonymous with St Augustine and then attaching it to the entire Latin Church from his time forward is fallacious because the term has always been used to describe the teachings of the Latin fathers on the Fall before and after St Augustine (not only for a particular person’s articulation). It is also demonstrated by the fact that the Latin Church never endorsed all of Augustine’s minute articulations and continued to articulate through the centuries her own [the Latin Church] detailed expositions in light of our shared tradition. Today, for example, if one reads the articulations presented in the Catechism of the Catholic Church (1992) side by side our Councils, our catechisms not written from the perspective of the Neo Patristics movement, and expositions one would not be able to discern any essential differences.
https://journal.orthodoxwestblogs.com/2019/01/24/original-and-ancestral-sin-a-church-dividing-issue/

And here from a Catholic perspective:

>[The EO] seem to think the doctrine presented [in the Catholic Catechism] is a new interpretation, when in fact it is the doctrine of Thomas Aquinas and of practically all the Catholic doctors who interpreted Augustine.
https://www.catholic.com/magazine/online-edition/where-the-orthodox-meet-original-sin


>The Orthodox and high Protestant position is that Mary was born like anyone else, but that God protected her from sinning.
There is substantial evidence in the Eastern Fathers of belief in Mary's προκαθαρθείσα (“prepurification”), a belief that accords closely, if not quite exactly, with the Catholic doctrine of the Immaculate Conception. The argument is summarized here:

https://hortulus-journal.com/journal/volume-13-number-1-2017/cuff/

>I'm asking Catholics why it's necessary.
It's fitting and proper. It follows from the Fathers' understanding of Mary as the second Eve*, just as Christ was the second Adam.

Now, Adam was created without original sin, likewise Eve.

Thus it was fitting and proper that just as the second Adam, Christ, was born without original sin, so too should His mother, the second Eve.

Likewise, it is fitting for the following reason.
Jesus Christ was truly man along with being truly God. He had real, literal, physical flesh, and that flesh came from Mary alone because He had no earthly father. If Mary was a sinner then Jesus Christ's own flesh would be formed out of the flesh tainted with original sin. Again, that would be inconsistent with Christ's role in salvation history as the Second Adam. 1 Cor. 15:45, Romans 5:14.

Testimony of the Fathers respecting Mary as the Second Eve:

St. Justin Martyr:
For Eve, being a virgin and undefiled, conceiving the word that was from the serpent, brought forth disobedience and death; but the Virgin Mary, taking faith and joy, when the Angel told her the good tidings, that the Spirit of the Lord should come upon her and the power of the Highest overshadow her, and therefore the Holy One that was born of her was Son of God, answered, 'Be it to me according to Thy word.'

Tertullian:
God recovered His image and likeness, which the devil had seized, by a rival operation. For into Eve, as yet a virgin, had crept the word which was the framer of death. Equally into a virgin was to be introduced the Word of God which was the builder-up of life; that, what by that sex had gone into perdition, by the same sex might be brought back to salvation. Eve had believed the serpent; Mary believed Gabriel; the fault which the one committed by believing, the other by believing has blotted out.

Irenaeus:
And so the knot of Eye's disobedience received its unloosing through the obedience of Mary; for what Eve, a virgin, bound by incredulity, that Mary, a virgin, unloosed by faith.

St. Cyril of Jerusalem:
Since through Eve, a virgin, came death, it behooved, that through a Virgin, or rather from a Virgin, should life appear; that, as the Serpent had deceived the one, so to the other Gabriel might bring good tidings.

I'm always a bit worried when someone new publishes a rhyming version of Dante, in case it's better than mine, but fortunately they're all terrible.


——— CANTO III ———


THROUGH ME IS FOUND THE CITY OF DESPAIR:
THROUGH ME TO PAIN WHICH CANNOT BE REMOVED:
THROUGH ME TO SOULS BEYOND THE REACH OF PRAYER.

JUSTICE IMPELLED MY MAKER HIGH ABOVE:
BY GOD'S DIVINE STRENGTH WAS I ENGINEERED,
WISDOM SUPREME, AND FUNDAMENTAL LOVE.

BEFORE ME THINGS THAT MOCK THE PASSING YEAR
ALONE WERE MADE, AND THUS DO I ENDURE:
ALL HOPE ABANDON, YE THAT ENTER HERE.

These words, inscribed in colours most obscure,
I saw above a gate. "Master," I said,
"What is their meaning? I cannot be sure."

And he replied, who had the wiser head:
"From this point you must leave distrust behind:
All cowardice within you must be dead.

This is the region in whose depths we'll find,
As I described, those wretched souls distressed
Who've lost the guiding light of heart and mind."

He took my hand and with his cheer impressed
Me so, my spirits soon began to rise.
Towards these hidden things we now progressed.

Here suspiration, sobs, and heartfelt cries
Echoed through air unlit by any star,
So that at first the tears came to my eyes.

Horrific shrieks, tongues foreign and bizarre,
Strange words of anguish, voices raised in strife,
Hoarse tones and clapping hands, made near and far

A tumult which was everywhere so rife
It painted thick the atmosphere, like grains
Of sand breathed by a whirlwind into life.

It would be nice to see it published in some form. I'll happily accept help from anyone who thinks he can make that more likely. (I never really expected to make any money from it.) There are several issues:

— I wrote it more-or-less in order. This meant the Paradiso was noticeably smoother, as I'd had the practice of writing the other two books. After finishing the whole thing I left it a few weeks and then went back and re-read it and found parts, particularly early on, that needed work. I've done most of them, but it still needs a little polishing.

— It needs footnotes (my current plan is to put them at the end of each canto). They shouldn't take long, though. A single-volume work should be about 500 pages maximum, I guess. My current working text is A4 paper with 12-point font, which fits about 15 3-line stanzas per page and comes out at 400 pages exactly. Not sure how that would translate to a printed book, but any notes would have to be brief. (An electronic version could be longer, I suppose.)

— One person on /wsr/ said the only chance to get any sales at all was to find some unique selling point. He suggested incorporating good illustrations and trying to make a sort of coffee-table book. That would mean finding a collaborator, though, which would just make it less likely the whole project ever got off the ground. (I did consider large illuminated letters for the start of each canto, incorporating something from that particular chapter. For example, Canto 1 of the Inferno could have a leopard prowling round its base.)


>and the rest of the book is of similar quality to the part posted
It's hard to judge a work when you've been inside it for so long. I get the feeling it's fairly uniform in quality overall (perhaps improving as it goes, as I mentioned above). On the smaller scale, some bits obviously work better than others; it's mostly a matter of luck with the rhymes. If anyone wants to see any particular section, just let me know which and I'll post it. Picture attached is from the end of the Purgatorio, when Dante finally meets Beatrice.

Forster was an admirer of the poet, philosopher, socialist, and early gay activist Edward Carpenter and, following a visit to Carpenter's home at Millthorpe, Derbyshire in 1913, was inspired to write Maurice. The cross-class relationship between Carpenter and his working-class partner, George Merrill, presented a real-life model for that of Maurice and Alec Scudder.

The bottom line is that literary fiction needs to adapt or die. It's a good sign that there are experiments in that direction, because trying to do things like combine fantasy and literary is at least an attempt to create a signal that will reach someone out there. Too many retards think it's somehow noble or a sign of taste, education, moral distinction, or laudable anti-consumerism to write shit nobody wants to read. In that case, enjoy being the highest status faggot left in the English department as the funding dries up and your novel you spent 5 years perfecting with the support and guidance of your likeminded colleagues sold a total of 8 copies to your family and friends.

I'm not sure what the answer is, but people too often focus on the death of the literary as if it is explained only by the flaws and inadequacies of the modern reader and by changes in the wider culture. Literary fiction, literary fiction writers, and literary institutions and culture have also changed, and not in a good way.

The white dudes who would be writing literary fiction now are into politics, genre fiction, or poetry instead. Basically our world has gotten so ugly that you either address the problem head on (politics), extract the very best of it (poetry), or just create your own world (genre fic).

OP mentions DFW. Back in the 90s it was still possible to believe that maybe things would turn out fine. Neoliberalism looks sketchy but hey, the economy is booming! Berlin Wall is gone, we basically have world peace right? 9/11 was the chink in the armor but 2008, 2016, and 2020 were all deadly years, so DFW-style optimism is untenable now. Just imagine writing Infinite Jest nowadays, a book about being bored with a comfortable middle class lifestyle and searching for deeper meaning, as the whole middle class evaporates. Zoomers have (unconsciously) realized we're at the beginning of the decline, it's not really something you can put into words easily.

Maybe there is material for a great novel in there though.

>>21571856
I’m 19 now and I think the heart of the matter is that I no longer know on what basis I speak to myself. I can ask superficial to relatively personal questions and all I get back from the other, disconnected voice in my head is an answer, certainly, but one that lacks real weight or significance. Even in my head there is no unifying principle, belief, or teleology, and with that comes a general lack of investment in the external. The computer assumes its talking to itself, and I don’t mean this in any pitiable way; under no circumstances would I want to change my thought process but there is a feeling of consistent homelessness and living life, even the immediate present, in perpetual hindsight. My thought process, when not attempting to set aside the time to converse with myself, is oriented on both an awareness of cliche and expectation, bated breath for nothing much, as well as highly conceptual, both visual and metaphorical, sort of diagrammatic. I’m not sure how other zoomers feel but at the very least it’s easy to tell how disconnected they are, thin faces caught between the lazy tugs of their consciousness and the world around them, indifferent to which plops in the mud. I have at least two good friends who I admire intellectually and, to an extent, ethically and this at least gives me some small cutlet of hope for the cultural output to come.

Alienation comes from the division of labour, you makes goods and provide services that you do not use yourself, but instead sell to others on a marketplace, where your human labour input is revalued as an inhuman dollar cost. Eliminating alienation is an economy is valuing the human labour input as human, not as an abstract dollar amount.

Seems Utopian to me, but I can understand reducing or increasing the degree of alienation by reducing or increasing the degree of dehumanisation of the labor input, as in conditions of higher wages and better conditions, or slavery. I don't see how you can have division of labor without an inherant degree of alienation.

Physical journal for a more therapeutic approach
Digital journal for thought/idea organization

For retention? Writing is a scam. Use a 'memory palace' (or rather, memory solitary confinement) that uses suffering as it's mnemonic reinforcement. I like to deprive myself of sleep and enter into trances and manic episodes where, being so strung out, I am able to suspend my judgement and deduct information about the world using as few data points as possible. Of course the sum is unconveyable, because it is distributed throughout my entire system as actualization.
Conjunct this investigation with a physical tic, like pacing or humming, and the experience is burned into the depths of my mind as pure intuition/internalization, subconsciously deployed in-situ when required like cognitive muscle memory, and is far superior to being forced to dredge up information.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
'A Perfect Vacuum' is very /lit/, reviews of non-existent books (ideas Lem had, but felt himself disinterested to fully flesh out into a whole novel):
>While reviewing nonexistent books, a modern form of pseudepigraphy, Stanisław Lem attempted to create different fictional reviewers and authors for each of the books. In his own words: "I tried to imitate various styles – that of a book review, a lecture, a presentation, a speech (of a Nobel Prize laureate) and so on".[3] Some of the reviews are lighthearted, concentrating mostly on the story; others, however, read more like serious, academic reviews. Some of the reviews are parodies, or the books being reviewed are parodies or complete impossibilities, others are quite serious and can be seen almost as drafts for novels that Lem never got around to write.[1] Lem wrote: "With years passing a great impatience grew in me. It would be a hard work to convert ideas into narration, and that was one of the main reasons I went for such cruel abridgements of the books".[2][3] Lem was not alone in passing through this kind of crisis: examples abound of works planned by literary celebrities, but never completed.[4] Lem also remarked that he was eventually convinced that writing summaries and introductions enabled him to save time on producing things of importance, namely, his modeling experiments, compared to full-blown literary efforts, most of which would have constituted mundane craftsmanship.[3]

There's a few objections that can be raised to this off the top of my head:
1. You are simultaneously assuming that time matters to timeless things AND rejecting that these things are timeless because time applies to them; nothing suggests that time here actually affects the world of forms, in fact if there is any relationship it is probably the inverse.

>>21576228
Parmenides 130c-e:

>"Well then, Socrates, what about those things that would seem to be laughable, such as Hair and Mud and Dirt or any different thing that's very worthless and lowly? Are you at an impasse over whether it is or is not necessary to say that there is a separate form ofeach of these, something different than what we can lay our hands on?"

>"No, not at all!" answered Socrates. "For these things are as we see them right here, and it would be grossly out of place to think that there is some form of them. To be sure, it has troubled me that the same case does not apply to all, but whenever I come to this, I run off, fearing to fall and perish in some abyss of foolishness. In the end, then, I return to these things that just now we were saying are forms and I spend my time working over them."

>"Well, you are still young, Socrates," said Parmenides, "*and philosophy has not yet grabbed you as it will, in my opinion. Then you will dishonor none of these things; but as for now, you still look to the opinions of men, because of your age.*"

That is, there might or might not be a form of mud, but Socrates hasn't hypothesized about it at all, because he accepts it's as worthless and lowly as everyone says.

Suppose I take a bit of that mud. Is the car still stuck in the same mud or it is suddenly stuck in a different one? What if I pour ten gallons more mud instead? Is it still the same mud? How do you identify that mud as itself, what makes that particular bit of mud itself? You can stick to the colour, sure, but that's not all the red mud in the world - then you would need to differentiate it from the rest of the red mud. But forget that, let's make this harder - how about considering all the red mud in the world as one pile, is it distinct as its own type of mud, separate from other types on the basis of its colour? We might be tempted to say yes, but the fact is that even this red mud will not be uniformly red. It will not be one mud, or a mud - it will just be a bunch of mud. And the same applies to the example you gave, at a lower scale of course.
Mud-as-such is an unbound substrate and therefore indefinite, it cannot be outlined either on the basis of any special intelligible qualities or even on the basis of some kind of limit, because a purely physical limit is not a very strict thing.

Those Jews of the second temple era had their own temple at Elphantine, were polytheists who worshipped other gods alongside Yahweh, had a fasting ritual akin to passover without any of the passover names or particularities, worked on the Sabbath without a hint of shame or illicity, and so on. >>21575100
Posting the opening:

I am writing in the library of a manor-house, in a village I prefer not to name, near the town of Kunmadaras, in Szolnok County.

These words trailing away behind the point of my pen are words from my native language. Heavy-hearted Magyar, my editor calls it. She may well be right. These words rest lightly on my page, but this heaviness pressing on me is perhaps the weight of all the words I have still not written. And the heaviness pressing on me is what first urged me to write.

Or the heaviness pressing on me could be the weight of all the days I have still not lived. My heaviness will urge me in a little while to get up from this table and to walk to the windows; but the same heaviness will urge me afterwards to sit down again at this table. Then, if I begin to write: I walked just now to the windows and looked across my estates... my reader will learn how little I see around me, with this heaviness pressing on me. Of all the wide landscapes around my manor-house, I can never bring to mind any more than the nearest field and the long line of poplar trees on the far side of it.

Is that really all? Sometimes I am aware of more fields behind the first field, and of grasslands behind everything – indistinct grasslands under grey, sagging clouds. And I could repeat a sentence or two from my schooldays: Szolnok County, on the Great Alfold...I have forgotten for the moment what I once read in my schoolbook. But I remember the sweep-arm well in the first field behind the poplar trees.

If you, my reader, could step with me to the windows, you would notice it at once – the long pole pointing at the sky. You would notice the well-pole, but why should I? A long pole points at the sky in every view from every window in this manor-house, and in every view from every manor-house in Szolnok County. Yet again, neither you nor I might see a particular well-pole on the far side of the poplars; one of my overseers was ordered to block the well and to pull down the pole last year – or it may have been another year.

Now, something other than heaviness urges me to leave this table and to walk to the windows. I have to walk to the windows in order to learn whether I remembered, just now, the sight of a certain well, or whether I was dreaming.
But perhaps I could say without leaving this table that I only dreamed of the sight of my well. If you recall, reader, I had not left my table when I began this inquiry. I had only dreamed of myself leaving my table and then returning to my table and then trying to recall what I might have seen through my windows. I dreamed of myself here at my table and then I wondered whether the man I dreamed of – whether that man remembered the sight of a certain well or whether he was dreaming.

Anne Kristaly Gunnarsen translates much more than names of grasses and shrubs. She is director of the Bureau for the Exchange of Data on Grasslands and Prairies. The Bureau is a department within the Institute of Prairie Studies.

When I first heard of the Bureau, I dreamed of a large American building crowded with filing cabinets and desks and with clerks wearing green eyeshades. But Anne Kristaly Gunnarsen speaks lightly of the Bureau. She tells me it is literally a desk – the same desk from which she writes to me. And she diminishes the Bureau by naming it from the initial letters of its title.

Sometimes Anne Kristaly Gunnarsen describes herself sitting at her desk and thinking of the grasslands of the world. At every hour of the day, in one country or another, a man looks up from peering at plants with names such as ironweed or wolfberry. The man is the only person inside the circle of the horizon. He stares across the veldt or the steppes or the pampas and prepares to think of himself as quite alone. But he cannot think of himself and the grass around his knees and the clouds over his head and nothing more. He thinks of himself talking or writing to a young woman. He thinks of himself telling the young woman that he thinks of her whenever he finds himself alone in grasslands. He thinks of himself telling the young woman that he thinks of her telling him she thinks of a man such as himself whenever she sits at her desk and thinks of the grasslands of the world

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
"Helvetica" edition.

There wouldn't be /lit/ at all if there weren't letters. Even before printing there were distinct and recognisable 'types' of writing, and now after 500 years of printing in Europe and about twice as much in China there are a whole lot more. You're looking at a typeface right now. Even if you don't notice typography, you are still noticing it.

In this thread, discuss typography and topics related to typography. What fonts do you like? Dislike? What fonts do you use in your everyday typing? What's an example of a particularly well-typeset book? Do you think sans-serif fonts for body text in printed books are hard to read? Does bad kerning make you grind your teeth? Is there a particular font you've seen somewhere but can't identify? Any and all questions are welcome.

——Books on Typography——
—Bringhurst, Robert. The Elements of Typographic Style
—Dowding, Geoffrey. Finer Points in the Spacing and Arrangement of the Printed Word.
—Gill, Eric. An Essay on Typography.
—Lawson, Alexander. Anatomy of a Typeface.
—Tschichold, Jan. The New Typography.
—McLean, Ruari. The Thames and Hudson Manual of Typography.
—Heller, Steven; Meggs, Philip B. Texts on Type: Critical Writings on Typography.

——Online Typography Resources——
https://github.com/brabadu/awesome-fonts

It's not that Peterson is wrong so much as he vastly oversells how comforting that idea actually is. Humans don't live in systems where individuals are split off from groups and placed in the location where they are maximally efficient in furthering the needs of the group. In olden days they just accepted roles tended to follow family lines and letting the occasional retard be king was the price of avoiding civil war, because on average his family is still stronger than any other. Even if competence works overtime, there can be galling inefficiencies along the way.

Modern society tries to place individuals meritocratically, but the systems they work in can become so bloated and corrupt that those people damage the societies they live in without knowing (or caring). What actually brings meritocracy and reality together is conflict between groups, which Peterson never likes to bring up. The current managerial elite and their hangers on have not been seriously tested and probably won't survive the next big crisis in their current form, but again, Peterson applies his models in broad strokes and ignores the concrete instances.

I read about 60-70. I do make general plans (like, I don’t pick up a big difficult book if I know things will be busy next week). But otherwise I don’t really plan the order in which I read them. I rarely read two books in the same genre/style/time period back to back, and I don’t read two fiction books in parallel.
I used to get really hung up on understanding everything the first time through a book but now I read faster and reread more. Once you’ve read a good chunk of books from the same “movement,” they start to fill in one-another’s gaps. I think it’s helpful to cultivate a fast and slow reading speed for this reason. (And obviously the good books I reread slowly.)

posts.name: Anonymous

>>21572132
> What non fiction topics are interesting to you?
Most things. From basic physics to electronics repair or psychology and politics. Some highlights from previous years included:
Are We Smart Enough to Know How Smart Animals Are by de Waal. Well written book on animal cognition with many direct references to experiments and studies.
Christianity by Diarmaid MacCullouch, 1100 page overview of history and theology. Very useful for understanding European history since the theological battles interweave and shape secular history, including the definition of what Europe is and isn’t (ref orthodoxy battles, east and west). Also interesting to learn about how truly divergent Christianity becomes the closer to Jesus you get.
On that note The Ark Before Noah by Irving Finkel was interesting. It deals with the flood and ark stories from a Babylonian cuneiform tablet and you begin to realize just how much of judaism (and consequently christianity) was stolen mythology. A bizarre amount of details predate any jewish account here.
Who Killed Homer was also interesting since it deals with the 90s era infestation of identity politics and how it worked to kill off the classics departments. I think people sometimes talk like there’s no precedent for what’s happening now and that it came out of the blue or from the net. It really didn’t. Precursors in the 70s, the 90s “new man” and (unironically and sincerely) “politically correct” should have been fought at the time.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
What are you doing is what Hegel calls thinking at the level of the Understanding, which necessarily thinks in terms of "finite" concepts, concepts that acquire their essence precisely by being delimited, de-fined (finis - end, limit), by being distinguished from what they are NOT, thus, by NOT capturing the whole of something. The very usefulness of concept-thinking, Understanding (Verstand), comes from its delimitation and "giving up" of the in-finite Ideas of Reason. It is useful for carving up domains of inquiry or experience into corresponding binary categorizations: Is this X or Not X?

But Reason, Vernunft, which is higher than Verstand, thinks in Ideas, which reconcile the antinomies of the Understanding. What Kant describes in the second part of the Critique of Pure Reason as the antinomies and paradoxes generated by Reason, Hegel takes as a starting point for Reason's reconciliation of the antinomies.

>>21575327

The statement asserts that the fundamental laws of logic, which dictate that something cannot simultaneously be and not be, are in conflict with the observed phenomenon of objects and entities coming into and out of existence. However, this apparent contradiction can be reconciled through the application of a more nuanced understanding of the nature of existence and non-existence.
One possible explanation is that existence and non-existence are not binary states, but rather exist on a spectrum. The concept of potentiality and actuality, as espoused by philosophers such as Aristotle, posits that an object or entity may possess the potential to exist, but only actualizes that existence under certain conditions. Similarly, the concept of supervenience, which holds that the properties of a system are dependent upon the properties of its parts, suggests that the apparent transition from existence to non-existence may simply be a change in the arrangement or configuration of those parts.
Additionally, one may also argue that the concept of causality can be invoked to reconcile this apparent contradiction. The principle of causality posits that every event or change in the universe must have a cause, and that cause in turn must have a cause, and so on. Thus, the transition from existence to non-existence can be understood as the result of a chain of causality, rather than as a violation of logical principles. Furthermore, one may also argue that the observed phenomenon of the coming and going of entities may not necessarily be evidence of a violation of logic, but rather a result of the limitations of our senses and our ability to perceive and understand the world around us. The senses are fallible, and it is possible that the apparent transition from existence to non-existence is an illusion created by the limitations of our perception. Therefore, a more nuanced understanding of the nature of existence and non-existence, along with the principles of causality and potentiality and actuality, can reconcile the apparent contradiction between logic and the senses.

>>21573986
>>21575103
La colmena (the hive) is not really an enjoyable book, but it is imo one of the best portrayals of the depressing cicle of mediocrity that was life in 50s Spain.
The thing is that what makes it so good is that it portrays this mediocrity in a very non-dramatic way, just showing small bits of the life of a bunch of characters that feel like the sort of people that anyone back then probably knew one or two off, with none of them being some sort of tragic heroes or anything of the sort. It is just a book of tidbits of the life of some normal people with the intention of showing the reader how things were back then society-wise and letting them draw their own conclussions without going "le republicans bad" or "le franco bad".
It is a quite an interesting book if you are Spanish as it serves as kind of a window into the world that your parents/grandparents probably mentioned from time to time in passing, since most people don't like to talk about that period or don't have much to say becuse it was neither eventful nor overly tragic. Just a damaged and split society trying to get back to its feet by slogging through a very mediocre daily life
I really wouldn't reccomend it to non-spanish people unless they are very interested in 20th century Spain for some reason and/or already have some good knowledge about the time period.
(I tried to explain what makes the book interesting in more detail but i don't feel confident enough to explain it to someone who isn't in-the-know already, specially not in a second language)

Michael Lofton does yeoman's work defending the Pope against the many ill-founded accusations, and some not so ill-founded, that have been leveled against him:

https://www.youtube.com/@ReasonandTheology/search?query=francis

He explains his basic perspective, and his decision that the 'judgment of charity' is called for, here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gOpz1YMVYFc

In various of these he discusses in some detail whether the Pope can fairly be charged with heresy, and plausibly contends that the answer is no. Nor is he, in my view, being Pollyannaish in reaching this conclusion, or in defending the Pope generally. I am slightly chagrined to be directing you to a youtube commentator, but his remarks have been helpful to me, and I don't know of anyone else who addresses these issues in such granular detail.

> Is it wrong to say that the pope has been appointed by God, while also saying what he says is heretical?

"It is (objectively) a mortal sin of rash judgment for a person to decide that the pope is a formal heretic (and thus is no longer the pope)."

The reasoning undergirding this point is set out with some care in section 5 of this rather lengthy article:

https://catholiccandle.neocities.org/faith/against-sedevacantism

Section 7 through 9 are also relevant. Caveat: I think this article offers a sound articulation of Catholic doctrine, but I am not a theologian, so caveat emptor.

The high points in Church history, its moments of glory, are as fleeting as the hour of Christ's triumphal entry into Jerusalem. The Church passes through history like a ship battered by storms, more often in seeming peril of sinking than of enjoying a pacific and tranquil voyage.

"In the world ye shall have tribulation."

But the Gates have Hell have not prevailed against it, nor will they, if Christ's promise is to be trusted.

>So then why the fuck should I trust or believe in any of it?

In the 2000 year history of the Church there have been three Popes who present the "best case" scenario for having transgressed the Catholic claim of papal infallibility: Vigilius, Liberius, and Honorius.

It is important to note that the bishops of Vatican I (1870) carefully assessed each of these cases prior to deciding to enshrine papal infallibility as Church dogma. The key to understanding their reasoning is the relatively narrow scope of papal infallibility, which, in sum, applies only in cases where the pope is teaching formally in a matter of faith and morals. Thus, among other things, the Pope is not infallible when he speaks informally, or as a private person, or when under duress (e.g., when kidnapped and imprisoned, as happened to Pope Vigilius).

Catholic convert Ed Feser discusses the Honorius case here:

https://edwardfeser.blogspot.com/2022/10/the-error-and-condemnation-of-pope.html

Liberius and Vigilius are discussed briefly here:

https://www.patheos.com/blogs/davearmstrong/2016/06/honorius-disproof-of-papal-infallibility.html

If you really want to get into the weeds, the case of Vigilius, which is very complex, is analyzed at length here:

https://wherepeteris.com/was-pope-vigilius-a-heretic/

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21573072
Theology is theology.

Papal infallibility is narrowly defined. The 'ex cathedra' ("from the chair") idea comes from the Seat of Moses that Christ references:

>"The teachers of the law and the Pharisees sit in Moses' seat. So you must obey them and do everything they tell you. But do not do what they do, for they do not practice what they preach."
Matthew 23

Note how Christ distinguishes between formal pronouncements, which are binding, and bad behavior on the part of religious leaders, which poor example should not be followed. Indeed, regardless of whether those who teach are hypocrites, if they sit in Moses' Seat, their authority, when they speak authoritatively, must be obeyed. Was he splitting hairs, or laying down a sensible distinction?

In any event, this, among other scriptural passages, laid the foundation for what ultimately emerged as the Catholic understanding of papal infallibility.

If you want a quick rundown, you could read the entry in the Catholic Encyclopedia: https://www.newadvent.org/cathen/07790a.htm

>If you're going to claim that the Vatican has actually been compromised and that the people currently occupying it are heretics, you might as well not bother with the religion at all since you've already contradicted its fundamental premise. You don't get to opt out and decide not to obey the Pope...
